Description: Camel saddle with leather-covered wooden seat, wood frame and oval pommels, one at each end. A padded leather cushion is secured to the seat by means of two holes through which the pommels pass. The saddle is held together with leather thongs, metal plates and screws. Zig zag decorations have been cut into the leather seat cover below the pommels.
Curator's comments: Eth Doc.118. Saddle is typical of the type used by the Bedouin of the Egyptian and Eastern Cyrenaican desert, and was given to the donors in the late 1930's by Lamloun Pasha, the hereditary chief of the Bedouin of this region.
Condition: Well worn, but otherwise in fair condition.
Conservation: Surface cleaning to remove museum dirt, external surface particulate matter accumilated in museum storage.
